Action frames

Number of Frames: 18

FrameDescription
Ability to act
ActionAn action performed by an animate entity, prototypically involving motor-control.
Activity
Aids to action
Decision making
Difficulties in actionfactor(s) that negatively affect actor's ability to achieve objective
Force-applicationAction which involves transfer of force to another entity
Freedom of action
Immoral action
Increase ease of action
Moral action
Object manipulation
Purposeful actionAn action an actor performs with the intent of achieving some objective
Self propelled motionMoving entity supplies its own energy for its movement (along a path)
Self propelled motion to a destinationPerson moves towards a desirable location (or entity located there)
Self-initiated state changeExperiencer of state acts so as to change that state.
Sequence of actions
Social obligation

Causation frames

Number of Frames: 6

FrameDescription
Affected motionVery broad notion of "Caused Motion" which applies both to internal and external causal sources/forces, and in which the 'cause' can affect the motion in any one of various ways, including enabling, initiating,helping, impeding, or preventing a (potential) mover's motion.
Agentive causation
CausationThis is intended to be a very general schema that specifies a causal relation between two situations (a 'cause' and an 'effect'). Perhaps prototypically, cause and effect occur as part of a scenario in which the 'process' (casual_process) associated with one entity (the causer) is conceptualized as somehow affecting the process (affected_process) associated with another entity (affected). This very general frame is meant to encompass many different types of causes (including, e.g., both force-application and the lack thereof), different types of 'causal' relations (e.g. cause, prevent, enable, help, hinder), and different types of 'affected processes' (including, e.g., the motion, location, or state of the affected entity).
Caused change of state
Enablement
HarmScenario: negative impact to some entity, and the process that causes that harm

Force dynamic frames

Number of Frames: 8

FrameDescription
Antagonistic force
Destructive force
Force
Force transfer
Force-Dynamic InteractionOne entity (the force_originator) transfers force to another entity (force_receiver), which results in some outcome with respect to one or both entities. This is a general frame with more specific subcases that differ as to the intentions of the entities (when sentient), the details of the force-interaction, the relative strengths of the two entities, and the outcomes that result from the interaction.
Force-applicationAction which involves transfer of force to another entity
Object manipulation
Pressure


Change-related frames

Number of Frames: 5

FrameDescription
Caused change of state
Change of location
Change of state
Possession change
Self-initiated state changeExperiencer of state acts so as to change that state.

Competition frames

Number of Frames: 11

FrameDescription
CompetitionGeneric frame for any type of competition in which there are at least two sides competing for some advantageous outcome. See sub-cases for different types of competitions.
Competitive sportAny kind of sport which involves direct competition, either between individuals (e.g. singles tennis) or teams (eg. football). This frame does not include other forms of recreational competition that involve judges (e.g. figure skating) or timed events such as races.
Economic competitionCompetition between two entities (which may be people, corporations, countries, etc) over economic resources.
Election
Gambling
GameThis is the competitive version of game, where there are at least two players and there is an outcome with a winner and loser.
Physical competitionCompetition between two entities that involves physical contact; often with the goal of achieving a resource such as territory
Political competitionCompetition between two or more (groups of) people within a political context.
RaceTwo or more racers compete to finish a physical course first.
Recreational competitionSituations in which two or more (groups of) people compete for the entertainment of themselves and/or an audience
War

Motion impediments frames

Number of Frames: 18

FrameDescription
BarrierA physical object or landscape feature that prevents or makes it difficult for a mover to move in some (desired) direction
Barrier to accessing a location
Closing a portal
Confinement
Constructed Confinement
Constructed Restraints
ContainingA container object holds some sort of content object(s) or substance within its boundaries.
ContainmentA bounded region or object whose boundaries' physical properties prevent or impede motion
Environmental restraints
Freedom of action
Gap in pathA gap or geographic void that impedes or prevents motion along that path
Mazepathways that are confusing or difficult to navigate
Motion impedimentsThis is a generic frame that captures all kinds of impediments, whether they are obstacles in one's way, restraints, barriers, etc. This frame is unspecified as to the type of impediment.
Portals
Restraints
Sunken confinement
Trespassing
Water ConfinementPerson is in water or watery substance. This situation makes motion difficult (e.g. mire) and may also be dangerous to that person (they might drown)

Physical combat frame family

Number of Frames: 6

FrameDescription
AttackingAttacking actions performed on another animate entity
CompetitionGeneric frame for any type of competition in which there are at least two sides competing for some advantageous outcome. See sub-cases for different types of competitions.
Personal weaponWe may want to restrict this to Firearms (or Personal firearms), which would mean excluding things such as knives and bombs.
Physical combatFigthing between two or more people
Physical competitionCompetition between two entities that involves physical contact; often with the goal of achieving a resource such as territory

Physical properties frame family

Number of Frames: 13

FrameDescription
Decrease size
Firm
FitThe fit of one object against/next to another object.
Increase size
Lax
Loose fit
Physical attributes
Physical strengthThis frame is for the 'strong' end of the physical strength scale.
Physical strength scale
Physical weakness
SizeThe size of a bounded object or region, mostly conceptualized in terms of the amount of space it occupies. Particular sizes are generally defined in relation to some norm, and can be represented as positions on a 'size scale'.
Tight fit
Weight

Protect against contact
Protecting
Visual obstructionan entity that is between the see-er and the seen_object affects the see-er's ability to see all or part of that object (e.g. an obstructing entity prevents see-er from seeing something).
Wearable disguisesCreated to account for subtle frame differences in Disguise frame.

Translational motion frames

Number of Frames: 20

FrameDescription
Avoiding obstacles
Backward motion
Circular pathPath that goes in a circle; hence, it leads back to where it starts and the source = goal.
Downward motion
Forward motion
Journey
MotionThis is the most general Motion frame. Frame description: All or part of an entity (mover) moves with respect to some landmark or background. This general frame encompasses both "motion-in-place" (movement that can occur within a fixed location, e.g. spinning) and translational motion (in which the mover occupies a series of different locations over time -- see Motion_Along_A_Path). This frame could also be used to specify lack of motion (i.e. speed = 0).
Motion along a pathA moving entity starts out in one place and ends up in another, having traversed the distance between these places
Motion away from a bounded regionTranslational motion of some entity, with motion starting inside some (bounded) area, and ending outside that area
Motion away from a locationTranslational motion of some entity, away from some location
Motion away from an undesirable location
Motion to a bounded regionTranslational motion of some entity, with motion starting outside of some (bounded) area, and ending inside that area
Motion to a location
Motion to avoid a destination
Motion with respect to an undesirable entityMover moves so as to not be co-located with an undesirable entity.
Paths out of a locationA pathway that starts in a (bounded) area and ends outside of that area
Physical path
Self propelled motionMoving entity supplies its own energy for its movement (along a path)
Self propelled motion to a destinationPerson moves towards a desirable location (or entity located there)
Upward motion

Manner and path verbs

Number of Frames: 3

FrameDescription
Manner verbsThis frame is not a real frame. It is merely a container for verbs that express manner of motion. Sorry. I wish I didn't have to do this. :(
Neutral motion verbsThis frame is not a real frame. It is merely a container for verbs that express neither manner nor path of motion. Sorry. I wish I didn't have to do this. :(
Path verbsThis frame is not a real frame. It is merely a container for verbs that express path of motion. Sorry. I wish I didn't have to do this. :(

Zealotry Insanity Worship frame family

Insanity
WorshipUse of the language of religion to talk about dedication to an object/phenomenon.
Zealotrywildly excessive or irrational devotion, dedication, or enthusiasm


Democracy frames

Number of Frames: 9

FrameDescription
Citizen participation
DemocracyThis refers to the very notion of democracy. It is based on the 7 concepts submitted by us to IARPA in January 2014.

This is a macro-concept for the frames it subsumes.

The other 6 are Freedom, Equality, Democratic_institutions, Representation_and_decision-making, Organization_of_power, Citizen_participation
Democratic government
Democratic ideology
Equality
FreedomThe ideology of freedom rather than the physical impediment to motion
Organization of power
Representation and decision-making
Rights

CausationThis is intended to be a very general schema that specifies a causal relation between two situations (a 'cause' and an 'effect'). Perhaps prototypically, cause and effect occur as part of a scenario in which the 'process' (casual_process) associated with one entity (the causer) is conceptualized as somehow affecting the process (affected_process) associated with another entity (affected). This very general frame is meant to encompass many different types of causes (including, e.g., both force-application and the lack thereof), different types of 'causal' relations (e.g. cause, prevent, enable, help, hinder), and different types of 'affected processes' (including, e.g., the motion, location, or state of the affected entity).

Gun debate

Number of Frames: 24

FrameDescription
Constitution
Criminal gun violence
FreedomThe ideology of freedom rather than the physical impediment to motion
Gun controlA general frame for governmental controls on gun (and/or ammunition) ownership, use, sale, distribution, etc.
Gun control legislation
Gun debate
Gun industryThe manufacturing and sale of guns, any aspect of the industry.
Gun legislation
Gun possession
Gun rights
Gun rights legislation
Gun use
Gun-control advocacy
Gun-control advocate
Gun-rights advocacy
Gun-rights advocacy interest group
Gun-rights advocate
Injurious gun useThis general frame is intended to represent the commonalities across a range of contexts in which the discharge of a gun (potentially) results in injury to a person. Specific contexts, such as criminal use of guns, and sanctioned use of guns (e.g. by the police) can be elaborated in subcases.
Personal weaponWe may want to restrict this to Firearms (or Personal firearms), which would mean excluding things such as knives and bombs.
Right to self-defense
Safety
Second Amendmentviewpoint of the Second Amendment of the Constitution, which guarantees the "right to keep and bear arms", as Constitutional protection of gun rights
Self-defense
Weapons handling

Image Schemas

Number of Frames: 8

FrameDescription
Axis
Center periphery
Distant
Part whole
ProximalThe 'near' end of the proximity scale
Proximal distal
Proximity
Separation

Motion Frames

Number of Frames: 45

FrameDescription
Across
Affected motionVery broad notion of "Caused Motion" which applies both to internal and external causal sources/forces, and in which the 'cause' can affect the motion in any one of various ways, including enabling, initiating,helping, impeding, or preventing a (potential) mover's motion.
Aid to upward motion
Aids to downward motionobjects that facilitate downward motion
Aids to motion
Air motion
Backward motion
Boat motion x-schema
Caused downward motionMovement of an entity in a downward direction that is caused by some other entity or natural force
Caused upward motion
Downward motion
Fluid motionMotion of a fluid, along a path or within/across some area
Forced motionAn entity applies force to another entity, causing the second entity to move
Forward motion
Gap in pathA gap or geographic void that impedes or prevents motion along that path
Guided motion
Impediment to motionThis is a general frame that encapsulates both: active impediments of any kind (a subframe called Motion_impediments), and FAILURE TO enable (a subframe called Lack_of_enablement). Scenario: motion is impeded either by some barrier or antagonistic force; or by the failure to aid/enable motion
Impeding downward motionObjects that impede the downward motion of another entity.
Increase ease of motion
Lack of impediment to motion
Mass motionAggregate motion of a collection of entities acting as one
MotionThis is the most general Motion frame. Frame description: All or part of an entity (mover) moves with respect to some landmark or background. This general frame encompasses both "motion-in-place" (movement that can occur within a fixed location, e.g. spinning) and translational motion (in which the mover occupies a series of different locations over time -- see Motion_Along_A_Path). This frame could also be used to specify lack of motion (i.e. speed = 0).
Motion along a pathA moving entity starts out in one place and ends up in another, having traversed the distance between these places
Motion away from a bounded regionTranslational motion of some entity, with motion starting inside some (bounded) area, and ending outside that area
Motion away from a locationTranslational motion of some entity, away from some location
Motion away from an undesirable location
Motion back and forthnon-circular motion about a fixed location
Motion to a bounded regionTranslational motion of some entity, with motion starting outside of some (bounded) area, and ending inside that area
Motion to a location
Motion to avoid a destination
Motion with respect to an undesirable entityMover moves so as to not be co-located with an undesirable entity.
Motion-affecting actorsAn animate entity acts on a potential mover (an object or other animate entity), negatively affecting that mover's ability to move.
Motion-affecting external factorsThis is a very high level frame. It refers to things/factors/processes/entities/conditions etc. external to a mover or moving entity, that can (either positively or negatively, unspecified) affect the mover's motion (motion here being unspecified as to whether or not it's on a path or goal-directed).
Motion-affecting forces
Motion-affecting properties of the landscape
Moving object
Non-translational motionNon-lexical frame for motion that does not involve SPG; types of motion-in-place
Paths out of a locationA pathway that starts in a (bounded) area and ends outside of that area
Pursue
Rotation
Self propelled motionMoving entity supplies its own energy for its movement (along a path)
Self propelled motion to a destinationPerson moves towards a desirable location (or entity located there)
Upward motion
Vehicular motion
Virtual motion

Scale
SizeThe size of a bounded object or region, mostly conceptualized in terms of the amount of space it occupies. Particular sizes are generally defined in relation to some norm, and can be represented as positions on a 'size scale'.

State-related frames

Number of Frames: 8

FrameDescription
Caused change of state
Change of state
Existencestasis
Experiencing a negative state
Experiencing a state
Improving a state
Self-initiated state changeExperiencer of state acts so as to change that state.
StateThis frame represents the association/relation between an entity (state_holder) and a property/state (state_type). Specific entities will differ as to which set of properties/states they can or are likely to be associated with. The current frame does not include a temporal component, and thus cannot be directly used to indicate the duration of a given state, or the change of states over time; these are handled by 'subcases' of this frame, such as Change of state and Experiencing a state, which do include temporal structure. In at least some cases, the properties may also be represented as separate, individual frames (e.g. Temperature, Size) which elaborate the internal structure and set of potential values of that property.
